Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the fact that the trains were recently made operational in Sydney, when in reality they were made operational in May 2019.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks sufficient evidence or support to prove that the trains were indeed manufactured under 'Make in India'.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the video of the double-decker metro train is evidence of the trains being manufactured under 'Make in India', without providing any concrete proof.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that the trains were manufactured by the French company Alstom, rather than being solely 'Made in India'.
Exist alternative explanation: There is an alternative explanation that the trains were manufactured by Alstom in India and delivered to Sydney, rather than being solely 'Made in India'.
Understate: The claim understates the fact that the video is from 2018, suggesting that the trains were recently made operational, when in fact they have been operational since May 2019.
Falters at times: The claim falters in accurately representing the timeline and details of the trains' manufacturing and operational status.
